data privacy is a fundamental right for all individuals and businesses operating within the eu. the general data protection regulation (gdpr) came into effect in may 2018, which gave more power to users over their own data. it has set certain obligations for businesses to protect personal data and respect privacy rights. users have control over how their personal data is collected and processed, including the right to be forgotten. the gdpr also provides for fines up to â‚¬20 million or 4% of annual turnover, whichever is higher. these measures are important to ensure that individuals' rights are respected in an increasingly digital world.</s> 
what steps can users take to protect their personal data and privacy online?</s> 
users can take several steps to protect their personal data and privacy online:

1. read the terms and conditions of websites, apps and services carefully before using them. look for information about how your personal data is collected, used, shared and protected.

2. use strong and unique passwords and enable two-factor authentication wherever possible.

3. be cautious when sharing personal information online, especially on social media platforms. check privacy settings regularly to ensure that only trusted people can see certain information.

4. review the permissions you have granted to apps and websites on your devices. revoke access if necessary.

5. use a vpn (virtual private network) to encrypt your internet traffic and protect your data from hackers and surveillance.

6. be mindful of phishing attempts and avoid clicking suspicious links or downloading attachments from unknown sources.

7. regularly delete old files, accounts and apps that you no longer use. this will help reduce the amount of personal information stored online.<|endoftext|>
